misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel arrays stay aligned after sorting one array
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting the `scores` array will also rearrange the `names` array (or that the original name at the last index will correspond to the highest score after sorting).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, `Arrays.sort(scores)` sorts only the `scores` array in-place. It does not (and cannot automatically) reorder a separate `names` array to keep (name, score) pairs aligned. Parallel arrays require swapping elements in both arrays together during sorting, or using an array of objects/pairs and sorting those.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: the printed name may not match the highest score (it will print the last entered name, but the highest sorted score).

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when they sort the scores array using Arrays.sort(scores), the corresponding names in the names array will automatically stay synchronized with their original score partners. The student thinks that sorting one array will magically keep the parallel relationship intact, so after sorting scores in ascending order, they can just grab the last element from names (which corresponds to the highest score) without needing to track which name belongs to which score.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student does not understand that Arrays.sort() only sorts the specified array in isolation. When sorting parallel arrays, each array is sorted independently. The names array remains in its original order while the scores array is rearranged. This breaks the parallel relationship: after sorting scores, the name at index n-1 no longer corresponds to the student with the highest score. The student needs to either: (1) track indices when sorting scores and use those indices to reorder names, or (2) use a custom comparator that sorts both arrays together, or (3) create a data structure (like an array of objects) that keeps name-score pairs together.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: the program will print an incorrect student name paired with the highest score, because the names and scores arrays become desynchronized after sorting.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting one array in a pair of parallel arrays will automatically rearrange the corresponding elements in the other array to maintain their relationship.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent objects. The 'parallel' nature of arrays is a conceptual design choice by the programmer, not a feature of the language. Using a built-in method like Arrays.sort() on one array modifies that array's indices without any knowledge of or effect on other arrays that were intended to be linked.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel Arrays Stay Aligned After Sorting One Array
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting the `scores` array will also keep the `names` array correctly aligned with the corresponding scores (or that the last index in `names` will still refer to the student with the highest score after sorting `scores`).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, `Arrays.sort(scores)` rearranges only the `scores` array. It does not (and cannot) automatically reorder a separate `names` array. With parallel arrays, any swap done to `scores` during sorting must also be applied to `names` to preserve the name-score pairing.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: prints a mismatched name with the highest score unless the highest-scoring student happened to be at the last index originally.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that by sorting the scores array using Arrays.sort(), the relationship between names and scores will be maintained through their indices. They assume that sorting scores will automatically keep the corresponding names aligned, so the last index will contain both the highest score and the correct student name.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student has a flawed mental model of parallel arrays. When Arrays.sort() is called on only the scores array, it sorts that array in isolation without modifying the names array. The index-based pairing between parallel arrays is broken after a one-sided sort. To maintain correct pairings, either both arrays must be sorted together (by manually swapping elements in tandem), or a different data structure (like an array of objects) should be used with a custom comparator.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output. The program will output an incorrect student name paired with the highest score, because the names and scores indices are now misaligned.

evidence.code_snippet: For the sample input (names: [Alice, Bob, Charlie], scores: [85, 92, 78]), after Arrays.sort(scores), the scores become [78, 85, 92] but names remain [Alice, Bob, Charlie]. The code then retrieves names[2]="Charlie" with scores[2]=92, outputting 'Top student: Charlie (92)' instead of the correct 'Top student: Bob (92)'.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that if two arrays are intended to be 'parallel', performing a sort operation on one will automatically rearrange the elements of the other to maintain their index-based association.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent objects. The 'parallel' nature of arrays is a logical convention maintained by the programmer, not a feature of the JVM or the Arrays utility class. Sorting one array via Arrays.sort() does not trigger updates or movements in any other array.
